tests.title: NEET 2025 ‚Äì Chemistry (Physical) ‚Äì Thermodynamics ‚Äì Chapter Test ‚Äì 01
tests.instructions:
‚Ä¢ This is a Chapter-wise Test strictly based on NCERT.
‚Ä¢ Questions are selected as per NEET examination pattern.
‚Ä¢ Focus on accuracy rather than speed.
‚Ä¢ Negative marking is applicable.
‚Ä¢ Ideal for concept strengthening and revision.

questions.question: Thermodynamics is the branch of science that deals with:
options: Energy changes accompanying physical and chemical processes
questions.explanation: Thermodynamics deals with heat, work, and energy changes during processes.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which of the following is a state function?
questions.explanation: Internal energy depends only on state, not on path.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a state function?
questions.explanation: Work depends on the path followed.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: The first law of thermodynamics is a statement of conservation of:
questions.explanation: Energy can neither be created nor destroyed.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: The mathematical form of first law of thermodynamics is:
questions.explanation: Change in internal energy equals heat added plus work done on system.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For an isothermal expansion of ideal gas, ŒîU is:
questions.explanation: Internal energy of ideal gas depends only on temperature.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Work done in a reversible isothermal expansion of ideal gas is given by:
questions.explanation: Reversible isothermal work = ‚àínRT ln(V‚ÇÇ/V‚ÇÅ).
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Enthalpy (H) is defined as:
questions.explanation: Enthalpy is sum of internal energy and pressure-volume work.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: At constant pressure, heat absorbed by the system is equal to:
questions.explanation: At constant pressure, q‚Çö = ŒîH.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For an exothermic reaction, the value of ŒîH is:
questions.explanation: Exothermic reactions release heat, so ŒîH is negative.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Entropy is a measure of:
questions.explanation: Entropy represents degree of disorder or randomness.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For a spontaneous process, ŒîS_universe is:
questions.explanation: Second law states entropy of universe increases for spontaneous process.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which law introduces the concept of entropy?
questions.explanation: Second law of thermodynamics introduces entropy.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For a reversible process, change in entropy is given by:
questions.explanation: Entropy change is defined for reversible heat transfer.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Entropy change for an isolated system is:
questions.explanation: Entropy of isolated system never decreases.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Gibbs free energy (G) is defined as:
questions.explanation: G = H ‚àí TS.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For a spontaneous reaction at constant temperature and pressure, ŒîG is:
questions.explanation: Negative ŒîG indicates spontaneity.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: At equilibrium, Gibbs free energy change is:
questions.explanation: At equilibrium, ŒîG = 0.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which of the following conditions makes a reaction spontaneous at all temperatures?
questions.explanation: Negative ŒîH and positive ŒîS ensure spontaneity at all T.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: The unit of entropy is:
questions.explanation: Entropy has unit J mol‚Åª¬π K‚Åª¬π.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: The third law of thermodynamics states that entropy of a perfect crystal at 0 K is:
questions.explanation: Perfect crystal at absolute zero has zero entropy.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which of the following is an intensive property?
questions.explanation: Temperature does not depend on amount of substance.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which quantity determines the direction of a chemical reaction?
questions.explanation: Direction is decided by Gibbs free energy change.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For an adiabatic process, heat exchanged (q) is:
questions.explanation: No heat is exchanged in adiabatic process.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which process is reversible?
options: Isothermal expansion at infinitesimal pressure difference
questions.explanation: Reversible processes occur infinitely slowly.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which of the following reactions has ŒîS > 0?
questions.explanation: Entropy increases during phase change from liquid to gas.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For an ideal gas, internal energy depends on:
questions.explanation: Internal energy of ideal gas is function of temperature.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which law of thermodynamics defines temperature?
questions.explanation: Zeroth law establishes concept of temperature.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For an isobaric process, heat exchanged is equal to:
questions.explanation: At constant pressure, q = ŒîH.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: If ŒîH = ‚àí20 kJ and ŒîS = ‚àí50 J K‚Åª¬π, reaction is spontaneous at:
questions.explanation: ŒîG = ŒîH ‚àí TŒîS ‚Üí spontaneous at low T when ŒîG < 0.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which process increases entropy of universe?
questions.explanation: Entropy of universe increases in irreversible processes.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which condition gives maximum work?
questions.explanation: Maximum work is obtained in reversible process.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which quantity is path dependent?
questions.explanation: Work depends on path followed.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: The SI unit of work is:
questions.explanation: Work is measured in joules.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which reaction is endothermic?
questions.explanation: Photosynthesis absorbs energy.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which process has ŒîH = 0 for ideal gas?
questions.explanation: For ideal gas, ŒîH depends only on temperature.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: If ŒîG is positive, the reaction is:
questions.explanation: Positive ŒîG indicates non-spontaneous reaction.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which term measures useful work obtainable from a system?
questions.explanation: Gibbs free energy represents maximum useful work.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For a cyclic process, change in internal energy is:
questions.explanation: System returns to initial state in cyclic process.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which thermodynamic quantity predicts feasibility of a reaction?
questions.explanation: Feasibility is decided by Gibbs free energy change.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Calculate work done when 1 mol of an ideal gas expands reversibly and isothermally at 300 K from 10 L to 20 L. (R = 8.314 J mol‚Åª¬π K‚Åª¬π)
questions.explanation: w = ‚àínRT ln(V‚ÇÇ/V‚ÇÅ) = ‚àí1√ó8.314√ó300√óln2 ‚âà ‚àí1728 J (magnitude ‚âà 1728 J).
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For an isothermal expansion of an ideal gas, which quantity remains constant?
questions.explanation: In an isothermal process, temperature remains constant.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For an ideal gas undergoing isothermal expansion, ŒîU is:
questions.explanation: Internal energy of an ideal gas depends only on temperature.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Calculate heat absorbed when 2 mol of an ideal gas expands isothermally from 5 L to 20 L at 300 K.
questions.explanation: q = nRT ln(V‚ÇÇ/V‚ÇÅ) = 2√ó8.314√ó300√óln4 ‚âà 6912 J.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For an adiabatic process, which of the following is true?
questions.explanation: No heat exchange occurs in adiabatic process.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which process gives maximum work?
questions.explanation: Maximum work is obtained in reversible process.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For an isochoric process, work done is:
questions.explanation: Volume remains constant, so w = 0.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: If heat absorbed by a system is 500 J and work done by system is 200 J, calculate ŒîU.
questions.explanation: ŒîU = q ‚àí w = 500 ‚àí 200 = 300 J.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For an exothermic reaction, which statement is correct?
questions.explanation: Exothermic reactions have negative enthalpy change.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: If ŒîH = ‚àí100 kJ and ŒîS = +200 J K‚Åª¬π, reaction is spontaneous at:
questions.explanation: ŒîH < 0 and ŒîS > 0 ‚Üí spontaneous at all temperatures.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which condition makes a reaction non-spontaneous at all temperatures?
questions.explanation: Positive ŒîH and negative ŒîS always give positive ŒîG.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Calculate ŒîG at 298 K if ŒîH = ‚àí40 kJ and ŒîS = ‚àí100 J K‚Åª¬π.
questions.explanation: ŒîG = ŒîH ‚àí TŒîS = ‚àí40 ‚àí (298√ó‚àí0.1) ‚âà +10.2 kJ.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which quantity decides maximum non-PV work?
questions.explanation: Gibbs free energy gives maximum useful work.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: At equilibrium, which thermodynamic quantity is minimum?
questions.explanation: Gibbs free energy is minimum at equilibrium.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Entropy change for melting of ice at 0¬∞C is:
questions.explanation: Entropy increases when solid changes to liquid.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Calculate entropy change when 200 J of heat is absorbed reversibly at 400 K.
questions.explanation: ŒîS = q_rev/T = 200/400 = 0.5 J K‚Åª¬π.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which of the following increases entropy?
questions.explanation: Solid ‚Üí gas increases disorder.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which process has ŒîS = 0?
questions.explanation: System returns to initial state in cyclic process.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Entropy change of universe for spontaneous process is:
questions.explanation: ŒîS_universe > 0 for spontaneous processes.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which law states entropy of universe always increases?
questions.explanation: Second law introduces entropy concept.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For an ideal gas, ŒîH depends on:
questions.explanation: Enthalpy of ideal gas is function of temperature only.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which of the following is an extensive property?
questions.explanation: Entropy depends on amount of substance.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which quantity remains unchanged in an isolated system?
questions.explanation: Energy of isolated system remains constant.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which thermodynamic function predicts equilibrium?
questions.explanation: Equilibrium corresponds to minimum Gibbs free energy.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which process is irreversible?
questions.explanation: Free expansion is highly irreversible.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which quantity is always positive for spontaneous process?
questions.explanation: Entropy change of universe is positive.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: At absolute zero, entropy of a perfect crystal is:
questions.explanation: Third law of thermodynamics.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which reaction is endothermic?
questions.explanation: Photosynthesis absorbs energy.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For a spontaneous reaction at equilibrium, ŒîG is:
questions.explanation: At equilibrium, ŒîG = 0.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which quantity determines feasibility of reaction?
questions.explanation: Feasibility depends on Gibbs free energy.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which process has ŒîU = 0?
questions.explanation: For ideal gas, ŒîU depends only on temperature.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which law is the basis of temperature measurement?
questions.explanation: Zeroth law defines thermal equilibrium.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which function is minimum at equilibrium under constant T and P?
questions.explanation: Gibbs free energy is minimum.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which change increases entropy most?
questions.explanation: Liquid to gas gives maximum randomness.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which quantity has unit J K‚Åª¬π?
questions.explanation: Entropy unit is J K‚Åª¬π (or J mol‚Åª¬π K‚Åª¬π).
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For an irreversible process, work done is:
questions.explanation: Irreversible process gives less work than reversible.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which quantity is path independent?
questions.explanation: Entropy is a state function.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which reaction has ŒîS < 0?
questions.explanation: Gas to liquid decreases randomness.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For a reversible process, entropy change of universe is:
questions.explanation: Reversible process has ŒîS_universe = 0.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which thermodynamic quantity is conserved in isolated system?
questions.explanation: Energy of isolated system remains constant.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Calculate work done when 2 mol of an ideal gas expands reversibly and isothermally at 300 K from 2 L to 8 L. (R = 8.314 J mol‚Åª¬π K‚Åª¬π)
questions.explanation: w = ‚àínRT ln(V2/V1) = ‚àí2√ó8.314√ó300√óln4 ‚âà ‚àí6912 J (magnitude 6912 J).
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For an ideal gas, calculate ŒîU when temperature rises from 300 K to 400 K for 1 mol. (C·µ• = 12.5 J mol‚Åª¬π K‚Åª¬π)
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Calculate ŒîH for 2 mol of an ideal gas when temperature increases by 50 K. (C‚Çö = 20.8 J mol‚Åª¬π K‚Åª¬π)
questions.explanation: ŒîH = nC‚ÇöŒîT = 2√ó20.8√ó50 = 2080 J.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For a process, q = +500 J and ŒîU = +200 J. Calculate work done by the system.
questions.explanation: ŒîU = q ‚àí w ‚Üí w = q ‚àí ŒîU = 500 ‚àí 200 = 300 J (done by system).
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Calculate entropy change when 1000 J of heat is absorbed reversibly at 500 K.
questions.explanation: ŒîS = q_rev/T = 1000/500 = 2 J K‚Åª¬π.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For an isothermal reversible expansion of 1 mol ideal gas at 300 K, calculate work when volume doubles.
questions.explanation: w = ‚àínRT ln2 = ‚àí1√ó8.314√ó300√ó0.693 ‚âà ‚àí1728 J (magnitude 1728 J).
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: If ŒîH = ‚àí60 kJ and ŒîS = ‚àí150 J K‚Åª¬π, calculate ŒîG at 300 K.
questions.explanation: ŒîG = ŒîH ‚àí TŒîS = ‚àí60 ‚àí (300√ó‚àí0.150) = ‚àí60 + 45 = ‚àí15 kJ ‚ùå sign check ‚Üí actually +15 kJ.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: At what temperature will a reaction become spontaneous if ŒîH = +40 kJ and ŒîS = +100 J K‚Åª¬π?
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Calculate ŒîS for melting of ice at 273 K if ŒîH_fus = 6.0 kJ mol‚Åª¬π.
questions.explanation: ŒîS = ŒîH/T = 6000/273 ‚âà 22 J K‚Åª¬π mol‚Åª¬π.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For an adiabatic expansion of an ideal gas, which statement is correct?
questions.explanation: By definition, adiabatic process has q = 0.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Calculate work done in an irreversible expansion against constant external pressure of 1 atm when volume increases by 10 L.
questions.explanation: w = ‚àíP_extŒîV = ‚àí(1 atm)(10 L) ‚âà ‚àí1013 J.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For a cyclic process, which thermodynamic quantity is zero?
questions.explanation: In a cycle, system returns to initial state ‚Üí ŒîU = 0.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Calculate ŒîG if ŒîH = ‚àí120 kJ and ŒîS = +200 J K‚Åª¬π at 400 K.
questions.explanation: ŒîG = ‚àí120 ‚àí (400√ó0.200) = ‚àí120 ‚àí 80 = ‚àí200 kJ ‚ùå check: 200 J = 0.200 kJ ‚Üí 400√ó0.200 = 80 kJ ‚Üí ‚àí120 ‚àí (‚àí?) Actually ŒîS positive ‚Üí ‚àí120 ‚àí 80 = ‚àí200 kJ ‚Üí correct option ‚àí200 kJ.

questions.question: Which condition gives maximum PV work from a gas?

questions.question: For an ideal gas, relation between C‚Çö and C·µ• is:
questions.explanation: For ideal gas, C‚Çö ‚àí C·µ• = R, hence C‚Çö > C·µ•.

questions.question: Calculate ŒîU for isothermal expansion of ideal gas.
questions.explanation: ŒîU depends only on temperature; isothermal ‚Üí ŒîU = 0.

questions.question: Entropy change of universe for a reversible process is:

questions.explanation: ŒîS = q_rev/T = ‚àí500/250 = ‚àí2 J K‚Åª¬π.

questions.question: Which thermodynamic function is minimum at equilibrium (constant T, P)?
questions.explanation: At equilibrium, Gibbs free energy is minimum.

questions.question: For a reaction, ŒîG = ‚àíRT ln K. If K = 1, ŒîG is:

questions.question: Calculate ŒîG at 298 K if K = 10. (R = 8.314 J mol‚Åª¬π K‚Åª¬π)
questions.explanation: ŒîG = ‚àíRT lnK = ‚àí8.314√ó298√ó2.303√ólog10 ‚âà ‚àí5.7 kJ.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which process increases entropy the most?
questions.explanation: Liquid to gas gives maximum increase in randomness.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which thermodynamic quantity predicts feasibility of reaction?
questions.explanation: Feasibility is determined by Gibbs free energy change.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Calculate work done in free expansion of an ideal gas.
questions.explanation: Free expansion occurs against zero external pressure ‚Üí w = 0.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which quantity is path dependent?
questions.explanation: Work depends on path.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which thermodynamic law gives absolute entropy?
questions.explanation: Third law defines absolute entropy.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For a reversible isothermal expansion, heat absorbed is equal to:

questions.question: Which condition makes ŒîG most negative?

questions.question: Calculate ŒîS when 1 mol of ideal gas expands isothermally from V to 2V at 300 K.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which thermodynamic function is always positive for spontaneous process?
questions.explanation: For spontaneous process, ŒîS_universe > 0.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which process has maximum entropy?
questions.explanation: Gas has highest disorder among given states.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: At equilibrium under constant T and P, which quantity is zero?
questions.explanation: At equilibrium, ŒîG = 0.

questions.explanation: Entropy measures randomness/disorder.

questions.explanation: Internal energy of ideal gas is function of temperature only.

questions.question: Calculate entropy change when 1 mol of ideal gas expands reversibly and isothermally from 10 L to 40 L.
questions.explanation: ŒîS = nR ln(V‚ÇÇ/V‚ÇÅ) = 8.314 ln4 ‚âà 11.53 J K‚Åª¬π.

questions.question: Which process gives maximum entropy production?

questions.question: If ŒîG is negative and ŒîS is negative, reaction is spontaneous at:

questions.question: Calculate work done when gas expands irreversibly against constant pressure of 2 atm with ŒîV = 5 L.
questions.explanation: w = ‚àíPextŒîV = ‚àí2√ó5√ó101.3 ‚âà ‚àí5065 J.

questions.question: Which thermodynamic quantity decides spontaneity under constant T and V?
questions.explanation: At constant T and V, spontaneity depends on ŒîU ‚àí TŒîS.

questions.question: For a reaction, ŒîH = +30 kJ and ŒîS = ‚àí100 J K‚Åª¬π. Reaction is:

questions.question: Calculate ŒîG at 300 K if ŒîH = ‚àí90 kJ and ŒîS = ‚àí200 J K‚Åª¬π.
questions.explanation: ŒîG = ŒîH ‚àí TŒîS = ‚àí90 ‚àí (300√ó‚àí0.2) = ‚àí90 + 60 = +30 kJ.

questions.question: Which thermodynamic quantity is minimized in isolated system?

questions.question: Calculate entropy change of surroundings if system absorbs 1000 J heat at 250 K.
questions.explanation: ŒîS_sur = ‚àíq/T = ‚àí1000/250 = ‚àí4 J K‚Åª¬π.

questions.question: For an ideal gas, which quantity depends only on temperature?

questions.question: Which condition gives minimum work output?

questions.question: For a reaction, ŒîG = +5 kJ. Reaction can be made spontaneous by:

questions.question: Which quantity decides maximum electrical work?

questions.question: Which statement is correct for an isolated system?

questions.question: Which thermodynamic quantity cannot be measured absolutely?

questions.question: For a reaction, ŒîH = ‚àí50 kJ and ŒîS = +100 J K‚Åª¬π. Calculate ŒîG at 500 K.

questions.question: Which quantity determines spontaneity under constant T and P?

questions.question: Which thermodynamic quantity is path independent?

questions.question: Which reaction is spontaneous at all temperatures?

questions.question: Which quantity measures energy available to do useful work?

questions.question: Which process has maximum efficiency?
questions.explanation: Reversible (Carnot) cycle has maximum efficiency.

questions.question: Which quantity is zero at equilibrium?

questions.question: A particle moves along a straight line with velocity \(v = 3t^2 - 6t + 4\) (m/s). The acceleration at \(t = 2\,s\) is:
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: A body is projected vertically upward with speed 20 m/s. The maximum height reached (\(g=10\,m/s^2\)) is:
questions.explanation: Using \(v^2=u^2-2gh\), \(0=400-20h\Rightarrow h=20\,m\).
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: A block of mass 2 kg is acted upon by a force \(F=10\,N\). The acceleration produced is:
questions.explanation: Using Newton's second law, \(a=F/m=10/2=5\,m/s^2\).
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Work done by a constant force of 5 N moving a body by 4 m at 60¬∞ to force is:
questions.explanation: Work \(W=Fs\cos\theta=5\times4\times0.5=10\,J\).
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: The kinetic energy of a 1 kg body moving with speed 10 m/s is:
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Moment of inertia of a solid sphere of mass M and radius R about its diameter is:
questions.explanation: Standard result: \(I=\frac{2}{5}MR^2\).
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Angular momentum of a particle of mass m moving with velocity v at radius r is:
questions.explanation: Angular momentum \(L=mvr\).
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Escape velocity from Earth is proportional to:
questions.explanation: \(v_e=\sqrt{2gR}\Rightarrow v_e\propto\sqrt{gR}\).
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: The pressure at depth h in a liquid of density \(\rho\) is:
questions.explanation: Pressure due to liquid column is \(P=\rho gh\).
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: SI unit of coefficient of viscosity is:
questions.explanation: Viscosity unit is pascal-second (Pa¬∑s).
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: For an isothermal process of ideal gas, which remains constant?
questions.explanation: Isothermal process occurs at constant temperature.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Work done in isothermal expansion of ideal gas is given by:
questions.explanation: Work \(W=nRT\ln(V_2/V_1)\).
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Time period of simple pendulum of length l is:
questions.explanation: \(T=2\pi\sqrt{l/g}\).
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Frequency of SHM is independent of:
questions.explanation: For SHM, frequency does not depend on amplitude.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Wave speed on a stretched string depends on:
questions.explanation: \(v=\sqrt{T/\mu}\).
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Electric field due to point charge q at distance r is:
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Unit of electric flux is:
questions.explanation: Electric flux \(\Phi=E\cdot A\), unit N¬∑m^2/C.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Capacitance of parallel plate capacitor increases if:
questions.explanation: \(C=\varepsilon_0A/d\), smaller d increases C.

questions.question: Equivalent resistance of two 2Œ© resistors in parallel is:
questions.explanation: \(1/R=1/2+1/2=1\Rightarrow R=1\,\Omega\).

questions.question: Drift velocity of electrons increases with:

questions.question: Magnetic force on a charge q moving with velocity v in magnetic field B is:
questions.explanation: \(F=qvB\sin\theta\).

questions.question: Radius of circular path of charged particle in magnetic field is:

questions.question: Induced emf in a coil depends on:

questions.question: Reactance of capacitor in AC circuit is:
questions.explanation: Capacitive reactance \(X_C=1/\omega C\).

questions.question: Power factor of pure inductor is:
questions.explanation: Phase difference 90¬∞, so power factor cos90¬∞=0.

questions.question: Focal length of convex mirror is:
questions.explanation: By sign convention, convex mirror has negative focal length.

questions.question: Fringe width in Young's double slit experiment depends on:

questions.question: Photoelectric effect confirms the particle nature of:

questions.question: De Broglie wavelength of particle is:
questions.explanation: \(\lambda=h/p\).

questions.question: Half-life of radioactive substance depends on:

questions.explanation: Energy per photon = hc/Œª ‚âà 3.98√ó10^-19 J, photons/s = 100/3.98√ó10^-19 ‚âà 2.5√ó10^20.
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.question: For the reaction N2(g)+3H2(g)‚áå2NH3(g), if Kp = 4.0√ó10^8 at 500 K, then Kc is:
questions.explanation: Œîn = 2 ‚àí 4 = ‚àí2, Kp = Kc(RT)^‚àí2 ‚áí Kc = Kp(RT)^2 ‚âà 4√ó10^8√ó(41)^2 ‚âà 4√ó10^2.

questions.question: The molarity of pure water at 25¬∞C is approximately:

questions.question: Which of the following is a defining characteristic of members of Kingdom Monera as per NCERT?
questions.explanation: Members of Monera are prokaryotic and lack a membrane-bound nucleus.
questions.subject: Botany

questions.question: In angiosperms, the edible part of coconut is:
questions.explanation: Coconut water and kernel represent free-nuclear and cellular endosperm respectively.
questions.subject: Botany

questions.question: Which one of the following pairs is incorrectly matched?
questions.explanation: Trypanosoma belongs to Mastigophora, not Ciliata.
questions.subject: Botany

questions.question: The type of placentation found in tomato and lemon is:
questions.explanation: Tomato and lemon show axile placentation with ovules attached to a central axis.

questions.question: Which tissue is responsible for increase in girth of dicot stem?

questions.question: Casparian strips are characteristic of:
questions.explanation: Endodermal cells possess Casparian strips made of suberin.

questions.question: Which of the following is a reserve polysaccharide in plants?
questions.explanation: Starch is the reserve food material in plants.

questions.question: Which phase of cell cycle shows separation of sister chromatids?
questions.explanation: In anaphase, sister chromatids separate and move to opposite poles.

questions.question: The driving force for transpiration is:
questions.explanation: Loss of water from leaves generates transpiration pull.

questions.explanation: CO2 fixation in C4 plants initially forms oxaloacetic acid.

questions.explanation: Organic acids have RQ greater than 1.

questions.question: Double fertilisation is a characteristic feature of:

questions.question: Which crop variety is produced by mutation breeding?

questions.question: Which microorganism is used for production of cyclosporin A?

questions.question: Restriction enzymes belong to which class of enzymes?

questions.question: Bt toxin genes are obtained from:

questions.question: Population density is measured as:
questions.explanation: Population density refers to number of individuals per unit area.

questions.question: Biodiversity hotspots are characterised by:
questions.explanation: Hotspots show high species richness and high endemism.

questions.question: Montreal Protocol is associated with control of:

questions.question: Which plant shows symbiotic nitrogen fixation?

questions.question: The main carbohydrate translocated in plants is:
questions.explanation: Sucrose is the main translocated form of carbohydrate.

questions.question: Which deficiency causes interveinal chlorosis in young leaves?

questions.question: Which of the following character is common to all chordates?
options: Presence of notochord at some stage
questions.explanation: All chordates possess a notochord at least during some stage of their life cycle as stated in NCERT.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: In which phylum flame cells are the excretory structures?
questions.explanation: NCERT states that flame cells are the excretory structures in Platyhelminthes.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which class of animals shows jointed appendages and chitinous exoskeleton?
questions.explanation: All classes of Arthropoda possess jointed appendages and chitinous exoskeleton as per NCERT.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which nitrogenous waste is excreted by mammals?
questions.explanation: NCERT mentions mammals are ureotelic and excrete urea as the main nitrogenous waste.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which part of human alimentary canal secretes mucus but no digestive enzymes?
questions.explanation: Large intestine secretes mucus but does not secrete digestive enzymes according to NCERT.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Haemoglobin has greater affinity for which gas?
questions.explanation: NCERT states haemoglobin has about 200-300 times higher affinity for carbon monoxide than oxygen.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which blood group is known as universal donor?
questions.explanation: O‚àí blood group lacks A, B and Rh antigens and can donate to all groups as per NCERT.

questions.question: Which hormone is responsible for milk ejection from mammary glands?
questions.explanation: NCERT states oxytocin causes milk ejection by contraction of myoepithelial cells.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which stage of meiosis shows separation of homologous chromosomes?
questions.explanation: In Anaphase I homologous chromosomes separate as described in NCERT.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which type of inheritance is shown by sickle cell anaemia?
questions.explanation: NCERT states sickle cell anaemia is an autosomal recessive disorder.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which nitrogenous base is absent in RNA?
questions.explanation: RNA contains uracil instead of thymine as mentioned in NCERT.

questions.question: Which enzyme is responsible for joining Okazaki fragments?
questions.explanation: DNA ligase joins Okazaki fragments during DNA replication as per NCERT.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Who proposed the theory of natural selection?
questions.explanation: Charles Darwin proposed the theory of natural selection according to NCERT.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which disease is caused by Plasmodium?
questions.explanation: NCERT states malaria is caused by the protozoan parasite Plasmodium.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which microorganism is used for production of citric acid?
questions.explanation: NCERT mentions Aspergillus niger is used for commercial production of citric acid.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which enzyme is used in recombinant DNA technology to cut DNA?
questions.explanation: Restriction endonucleases cut DNA at specific recognition sites as per NCERT.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which population attribute is not an individual attribute?
questions.explanation: Age is an individual attribute while others are population attributes according to NCERT.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which trophic level has maximum energy?
questions.explanation: NCERT states producers contain maximum energy as energy decreases at each trophic level.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which biome is characterised by permafrost?
questions.explanation: Tundra biome is characterised by permafrost as per NCERT.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which gas is responsible for global warming?
questions.explanation: NCERT identifies carbon dioxide as a major greenhouse gas causing global warming.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which part of sperm contains mitochondria?
questions.explanation: Middle piece of sperm contains mitochondria arranged helically as per NCERT.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which hormone maintains pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Progesterone maintains pregnancy according to NCERT.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which vitamin deficiency causes night blindness?
questions.explanation: NCERT states deficiency of vitamin A causes night blindness.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which cell acts as the pacemaker of human heart?
questions.explanation: SA node initiates heartbeat and acts as pacemaker as per NCERT.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which hormone decreases blood glucose level?
questions.explanation: Insulin decreases blood glucose level according to NCERT.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which cranial nerve is responsible for vision?
questions.explanation: Optic nerve is responsible for vision as per NCERT.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which disorder is caused due to deficiency of iodine?
questions.explanation: NCERT states iodine deficiency causes goitre.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which disease is transmitted by female Anopheles mosquito?
questions.explanation: Female Anopheles mosquito transmits malaria as per NCERT.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which technique is used to separate DNA fragments?
questions.explanation: Gel electrophoresis separates DNA fragments based on size as mentioned in NCERT.
questions.subject: Zoology

questions.question: Which species has highest genetic diversity?
questions.explanation: NCERT states bacteria show highest genetic diversity.
questions.subject: Zoology

tests.title: NEET 2026 ‚Äì Physics ‚Äì Work, Energy & Power ‚Äì Chapter Test ‚Äì 01
tests.instructions:
‚Ä¢ This is a Chapter-wise Test strictly based on NCERT.
‚Ä¢ Questions are selected as per NEET examination pattern.
‚Ä¢ Focus on accuracy rather than speed.
‚Ä¢ Negative marking is applicable.
‚Ä¢ Ideal for concept strengthening and revision.

questions.question: Work done by a constant force \(\vec{F}\) acting on a particle displaced by \(\vec{s}\) is given by:
questions.explanation: Work done is the scalar product of force and displacement: \(W = \vec{F} \cdot \vec{s} = F s \cos \theta\).
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: The work done by centripetal force in circular motion is:
questions.explanation: Centripetal force is always perpendicular to displacement, so work done is zero.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: If displacement of a particle is zero, the work done by any force is:
questions.explanation: Work depends on displacement; zero displacement implies zero work.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which of the following is a scalar quantity?
questions.explanation: Work is a scalar quantity as it has magnitude only.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: The SI unit of work is:
questions.explanation: The SI unit of work is joule (J).
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: 1 joule is equal to:
questions.explanation: 1 joule = 1 newton √ó 1 metre.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: When the angle between force and displacement is 90¬∞, the work done is:
questions.explanation: At 90¬∞, \(\cos 90¬∞ = 0\), so work done is zero.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which of the following forces is conservative?
questions.explanation: Gravitational force is a conservative force.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Work done by a conservative force over a closed path is:
questions.explanation: Work done by a conservative force over a closed loop is zero.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Kinetic energy of a particle of mass \(m\) moving with velocity \(v\) is:
questions.explanation: Kinetic energy is given by \(K = \frac{1}{2}mv^2\).
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: If the speed of a particle is doubled, its kinetic energy becomes:
questions.explanation: Kinetic energy is proportional to square of speed.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Work-energy theorem states that work done by net force equals change in:
questions.explanation: Net work done equals change in kinetic energy.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: The work-energy theorem is valid for:
questions.explanation: Work-energy theorem is valid for all kinds of forces.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Potential energy associated with a conservative force depends on:
questions.explanation: Potential energy is a function of position only.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Gravitational potential energy near Earth's surface is:
questions.explanation: Near Earth surface, gravitational potential energy is \(U = mgh\).
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: The reference level for gravitational potential energy is:
questions.explanation: Reference level can be chosen arbitrarily.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Potential energy of a spring stretched by \(x\) is:
questions.explanation: Elastic potential energy is \(\frac{1}{2}kx^2\).
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: The spring force is a:
questions.explanation: Spring force is conservative.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Mechanical energy is the sum of:
questions.explanation: Mechanical energy = kinetic energy + potential energy.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: In absence of non-conservative forces, mechanical energy:
questions.explanation: Mechanical energy is conserved if only conservative forces act.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which of the following causes mechanical energy to decrease?
questions.explanation: Friction is a non-conservative force causing energy dissipation.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Power is defined as:
questions.explanation: Power is the rate of doing work.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: The SI unit of power is:
questions.explanation: SI unit of power is watt.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: 1 watt is equal to:
questions.explanation: 1 watt = 1 joule per second.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Instantaneous power delivered by a force \(\vec{F}\) to a particle moving with velocity \(\vec{v}\) is:
questions.explanation: Instantaneous power is the dot product of force and velocity.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: If force is perpendicular to velocity, instantaneous power is:
questions.explanation: Dot product is zero when vectors are perpendicular.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which of the following quantities has the same dimensions as work?
questions.explanation: Torque and work have same dimensions but different nature.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: The area under a force-displacement graph represents:
questions.explanation: Area under F‚Äìx graph gives work done.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: The area under a power-time graph represents:
questions.explanation: Area under P‚Äìt graph gives total work done.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: A body moving with constant speed in a circle has:
questions.explanation: Speed is constant, so kinetic energy remains constant.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which quantity is always conserved in elastic collisions?
questions.explanation: Both momentum and kinetic energy are conserved.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: In inelastic collision, which quantity is not conserved?
questions.explanation: Kinetic energy is not conserved in inelastic collisions.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: The work done by friction is generally:
questions.explanation: Friction opposes motion, so work done is negative.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: The unit of potential energy is:
questions.explanation: Potential energy has the same unit as work.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Mechanical energy of a freely falling body (neglecting air resistance):
questions.explanation: Mechanical energy is conserved.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a form of energy?
questions.explanation: Work is energy transfer, not a form of energy.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: The slope of kinetic energy vs velocity squared graph represents:
questions.explanation: Slope equals \(\frac{1}{2}m\), proportional to mass.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which of the following is path-independent?
questions.explanation: Gravitational force is conservative, so work is path-independent.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: The work done in stretching a spring slowly from 0 to x is:
questions.explanation: Work done equals elastic potential energy stored.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: The efficiency of a machine is always:
questions.explanation: Due to losses, efficiency cannot exceed unity.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which of the following has maximum power?
questions.explanation: Power depends on work done per unit time.
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question: A body of mass m moving with velocity v is stopped by friction. The work done by friction equals:
questions.explanation: Work done by friction equals negative of initial kinetic energy.

questions.question: The kinetic energy of a system depends on:

questions.question: Which compound is formed when sodium phenoxide reacts with ethyl iodide?
questions.explanation: Williamson synthesis of sodium phenoxide with ethyl iodide yields phenetole.
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.question: The reagent that differentiates primary, secondary and tertiary alcohols is Lucas reagent (conc. $HCl + ZnCl_2$). Which of the following reacts fastest?

questions.explanation: Boiling point increases with molecular mass due to stronger van der Waals forces.

questions.question: Which of the following is a *benzyl halide*?
questions.explanation: A benzyl halide has halogen attached to the carbon next to an aromatic ring.

questions.explanation: Benzyl carbocation is stabilized, favoring SN1.

questions.question: Which halide is most easily eliminated to give an alkene?

questions.explanation: Aqueous NaOH does not convert alcohol into haloalkane directly.
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.question: Which of the following is true about haloalkanes‚Äô boiling points?
questions.explanation: Haloalkanes‚Äô boiling points increase with molecular mass due to London forces.
questions.subject: Chemistry

tests.title: NEET 2026 ‚Äì Physics ‚Äì wave optics ‚Äì Chapter Test ‚Äì 01
tests.instructions:
‚Ä¢ Chapter-wise Test strictly based on NCERT.
‚Ä¢ Questions are selected as per NEET examination pattern.
‚Ä¢ Negative marking is applicable.

questions.question: In Young's double slit experiment, the condition for constructive interference at a point on the screen is:
questions.explanation: According to NCERT, constructive interference occurs when path difference equals integral multiple of wavelength.

questions.question: In Young's double slit experiment, fringe width is given by:
questions.explanation: NCERT gives fringe width Œ≤ = ŒªD/d, where D is screen distance and d is slit separation.

questions.question: In YDSE, if wavelength of light is doubled, fringe width becomes:
questions.explanation: Fringe width Œ≤ is directly proportional to wavelength Œª.

questions.question: In Young's double slit experiment, the central bright fringe is formed due to:
questions.explanation: At the center, path difference is zero, leading to constructive interference.

questions.question: In YDSE, if one slit is closed, the observed intensity on screen becomes:
questions.explanation: With one slit closed, interference disappears and uniform illumination is observed.

questions.question: In Young's double slit experiment, the fringe width depends on:
questions.explanation: Fringe width depends on wavelength Œª, screen distance D and slit separation d.

questions.question: The phenomenon of bending of light around obstacles is known as:
questions.explanation: NCERT defines diffraction as bending of light around obstacles or apertures.

questions.question: Diffraction effects are prominent when the size of obstacle is:
questions.explanation: Diffraction is significant when obstacle size is comparable to wavelength.

questions.question: In single slit diffraction, the condition for first minimum is:
questions.explanation: According to NCERT, minima occur at a sinŒ∏ = nŒª, first minimum at n=1.

questions.question: In single slit diffraction, the angular width of central maximum is:
questions.explanation: Angular width of central maximum is 2Œª/a as per NCERT.

questions.question: In diffraction, the central maximum is:
questions.explanation: NCERT states that central maximum is brightest and widest.

questions.question: In diffraction pattern, intensity of secondary maxima is:
questions.explanation: Secondary maxima have much lower intensity than central maximum.

questions.question: Resolving power of an optical instrument depends on:
questions.explanation: Resolving power depends on wavelength and aperture size.

questions.question: According to Rayleigh criterion, two point sources are just resolved when:
options: Central maximum of one falls on first minimum of other
questions.explanation: Rayleigh criterion states this condition for just resolution.

questions.question: Resolving power of telescope is given by:
questions.explanation: Resolving power is D/(1.22Œª) as per NCERT.

questions.question: Resolving power of microscope is directly proportional to:
questions.explanation: Resolving power increases with numerical aperture.

questions.question: Polarisation of light establishes that light waves are:
questions.explanation: Only transverse waves can be polarised.

questions.question: Unpolarised light consists of vibrations:
questions.explanation: Unpolarised light vibrates in all planes perpendicular to direction of propagation.

questions.question: Plane polarised light has vibrations confined to:
questions.explanation: Plane polarised light vibrates in a single plane.

questions.question: Brewster's law states that:
questions.explanation: NCERT gives Brewster's law as tanŒ∏B = refractive index.

questions.question: At Brewster angle, the reflected light is:
questions.explanation: At Brewster angle, reflected light becomes completely plane polarised.

questions.question: The angle between reflected and refracted rays at Brewster angle is:
questions.explanation: At Brewster angle, reflected and refracted rays are perpendicular.

questions.question: Malus' law relates intensity of polarised light to:
questions.explanation: Malus' law: I = I0 cos¬≤Œ∏.

questions.question: According to Malus' law, when analyser is at 90¬∞ to polariser, transmitted intensity is:
questions.explanation: At 90¬∞, cos¬≤90¬∞ = 0, hence zero intensity.

questions.question: If unpolarised light of intensity I0 passes through a polariser, transmitted intensity is:
questions.explanation: Polariser transmits half the intensity of unpolarised light.

questions.question: Phase difference between two interfering waves depends on:
questions.explanation: Phase difference is determined by path difference.

questions.question: In interference, redistribution of energy means:
options: Energy shifts from dark to bright fringes
questions.explanation: NCERT states energy is redistributed, not destroyed.

questions.question: Coherent sources are those which have:
questions.explanation: Coherent sources maintain constant phase difference.

questions.question: Two independent sodium lamps cannot produce sustained interference because:
questions.explanation: Independent sources do not maintain constant phase difference.

questions.question: In YDSE, if slit separation is increased, fringe width:
questions.explanation: Fringe width Œ≤ is inversely proportional to slit separation d.

questions.question: In diffraction grating, maximum intensity is observed when:
questions.explanation: Principal maxima occur when path difference equals integer multiple of wavelength.

questions.question: The condition for principal maxima in diffraction grating is:
questions.explanation: NCERT gives condition as d sinŒ∏ = nŒª.

questions.question: Diffraction grating produces sharper maxima than double slit because:
questions.explanation: More slits produce sharper principal maxima.

questions.question: The width of central maximum in diffraction decreases when:
questions.explanation: Central maximum width is inversely proportional to slit width.

questions.question: In single slit diffraction, secondary maxima are formed due to:
questions.explanation: Secondary maxima arise due to interference of secondary wavelets.

questions.question: The phenomenon responsible for colours seen in soap bubbles is:
questions.explanation: Colours in thin films are due to interference.

questions.question: In thin film interference, phase change of œÄ occurs on reflection from:
questions.explanation: Reflection from denser medium causes phase change of œÄ.

questions.question: In YDSE, if the entire apparatus is immersed in water, fringe width:
questions.explanation: Wavelength decreases in medium, hence fringe width decreases.

questions.question: The visibility of interference fringes depends on:
questions.explanation: Maximum visibility occurs when intensities are equal.

questions.question: In interference, dark fringes are formed due to:
questions.explanation: Dark fringes occur due to destructive interference.

questions.question: The resolving power of microscope increases when:
questions.explanation: Resolving power is inversely proportional to wavelength.

questions.question: Which phenomenon proves wave nature of light most directly?
questions.explanation: Diffraction is a direct consequence of wave nature.

questions.question: In diffraction grating, missing orders occur due to:
options: Overlap of diffraction minima and principal maxima
questions.explanation: Missing orders occur when principal maxima coincide with diffraction minima.

questions.question: In polarisation, the electric field vector vibrates:
questions.explanation: Electric field oscillates perpendicular to direction of propagation.

questions.question: If analyser is rotated continuously, intensity variation follows:
questions.explanation: Intensity follows Malus' law I = I0 cos¬≤Œ∏.

questions.question: In YDSE, fringe pattern disappears when:
questions.explanation: Incoherent sources cannot produce sustained interference.

questions.question: In diffraction, spreading of light is maximum when:
questions.explanation: Smaller aperture causes greater diffraction.

questions.question: Which of the following cannot be polarised?
questions.explanation: Sound waves are longitudinal and cannot be polarised.

questions.question: In YDSE, position of nth bright fringe from center is given by:
questions.explanation: Position of nth bright fringe y = nŒªD/d.

questions.question: The wavefront corresponding to a point source is:
questions.explanation: A point source produces spherical wavefronts as per NCERT.

questions.question: In Young's double slit experiment, the phase difference corresponding to the first dark fringe is:
questions.explanation: First dark fringe corresponds to destructive interference with phase difference œÄ.

questions.question: In YDSE, if the screen distance is doubled keeping other parameters same, fringe width becomes:
questions.explanation: Fringe width Œ≤ is directly proportional to screen distance D.

questions.question: The coherence length of light source depends on:
questions.explanation: Coherence length depends on frequency spread of the source.

questions.question: In interference, if intensities of two sources are I and 4I, the ratio of maximum to minimum intensity is:
In single slit diffraction, the linear width of central maximum on screen is proportional to:
questions.explanation: Linear width of central maximum is 2ŒªD/a.

questions.question: The first secondary maximum in single slit diffraction occurs approximately at:
questions.explanation: NCERT gives approximate condition for first secondary maximum at a sinŒ∏ ‚âà 1.43Œª.

questions.question: In diffraction, the energy missing from minima appears in:
questions.explanation: Energy redistributed from minima appears in secondary maxima.

questions.question: The resolving power of a telescope increases when:
questions.explanation: Resolving power is directly proportional to aperture diameter.

questions.question: The minimum angular separation that a telescope can resolve is:
questions.explanation: Rayleigh criterion gives minimum angular separation as 1.22Œª/D.

questions.question: In microscope, numerical aperture is defined as:
questions.explanation: Numerical aperture NA = Œº sinŒ∏ as per NCERT.

questions.question: Which of the following waves cannot show diffraction?
questions.explanation: Particle beams are not classical waves and do not show diffraction in NCERT context.

questions.question: The phenomenon of superposition of waves resulting in redistribution of intensity is called:
questions.explanation: Interference involves redistribution of intensity.

questions.question: In interference, the condition for minimum intensity is path difference:
questions.explanation: Destructive interference occurs at path difference (2n+1)Œª/2.

questions.question: If two waves of equal amplitude interfere constructively, the resultant amplitude is:
questions.explanation: Amplitudes add in phase, giving resultant 2A.

questions.question: In thin film interference, the colours depend on:
questions.explanation: Thin film colours depend on thickness, wavelength and angle.

questions.question: A plane wavefront corresponds to a source at:
questions.explanation: Plane wavefronts are produced by sources at infinity.

questions.question: The wavefront normal gives the direction of:
questions.explanation: Normal to wavefront indicates direction of propagation.

questions.question: Huygens' principle explains:
questions.explanation: Huygens' principle explains reflection, refraction and diffraction.

questions.question: According to Huygens' principle, each point on wavefront acts as:
questions.explanation: Each point acts as a secondary source of wavelets.

questions.question: In refraction, change in wavelength occurs due to change in:
questions.explanation: Speed of light changes in medium, causing wavelength change.

questions.question: In YDSE, coherence is achieved by:
options: Using same source and splitting wavefront
questions.explanation: Coherence is obtained by splitting wavefront of same source.

questions.question: In interference, if amplitudes are unequal, dark fringes are:
questions.explanation: Unequal amplitudes result in partially dark fringes.

questions.question: The phase difference between two points separated by distance Œª/4 is:
questions.explanation: Phase difference = 2œÄ(Œª/4)/Œª = œÄ/2.

questions.question: In diffraction grating, the order of spectrum increases when:
questions.explanation: Higher wavelength gives higher order for given grating.

questions.question: The dispersive power of a grating depends on:
questions.explanation: Dispersive power is proportional to order of spectrum.

questions.question: In polarisation, Brewster angle depends on:
questions.explanation: Brewster angle is determined by refractive index.

questions.question: If Œº increases, Brewster angle:
questions.explanation: tanŒ∏B = Œº, so Œ∏B increases with Œº.

questions.question: Circularly polarised light can be produced by:
questions.explanation: Quarter wave plate produces circular polarisation.

questions.question: A half wave plate changes:
questions.explanation: Half wave plate rotates plane of polarisation.

questions.question: The phenomenon of polarisation confirms that light is:
questions.explanation: Only transverse waves show polarisation.

questions.question: In YDSE using white light, central fringe is:
questions.explanation: Central fringe corresponds to zero path difference, hence white.

questions.question: In YDSE with white light, coloured fringes are observed near:
questions.explanation: Coloured fringes appear near central white fringe.

questions.question: The path difference corresponding to nth bright fringe is:
questions.explanation: Bright fringes occur at path difference nŒª.

questions.question: In diffraction, angular width of central maximum is independent of:
questions.explanation: Central maximum has no order dependence.

questions.question: The bending of light into the region of geometrical shadow is called:
questions.explanation: Diffraction causes bending into shadow region.

questions.question: In interference, the resultant intensity depends on:
questions.explanation: Resultant intensity depends on phase difference and amplitudes.

questions.question: The superposition principle is applicable when waves are:
questions.explanation: Superposition applies to linear wave systems.

questions.question: The condition for absence of a particular order in diffraction grating is:
questions.explanation: Missing order occurs when grating and diffraction conditions coincide.

questions.question: The angular separation between successive principal maxima in grating decreases when:
questions.explanation: Larger grating element reduces angular separation.

questions.question: In single slit diffraction, number of secondary maxima on each side is:
questions.explanation: Infinite secondary maxima are present on each side.

questions.question: In YDSE, if slit widths are unequal, fringe pattern becomes:
questions.explanation: Unequal slit widths cause unequal intensities.

questions.question: The minimum number of slits needed to observe sharp principal maxima is:
questions.explanation: Large number of slits produce sharp maxima.

questions.question: The electric vector in plane polarised light vibrates:
questions.explanation: Plane polarised light vibrates in one plane.

questions.question: In interference, if phase difference is zero, intensity is:
questions.explanation: Zero phase difference gives constructive interference.

questions.question: The visibility of fringes is maximum when amplitudes are:
questions.explanation: Equal amplitudes give maximum contrast.

questions.question: In diffraction grating, the angular width of principal maxima decreases when:
questions.explanation: More slits make maxima sharper.

questions.question: In YDSE, replacing air by glass will cause fringe width to:
questions.explanation: Wavelength decreases in glass, reducing fringe width.

questions.question: In thin film interference, destructive interference in reflected light occurs when path difference is:
questions.explanation: Including phase change, destructive condition is nŒª.

questions.question: Which of the following phenomena cannot be explained by particle nature of light?
questions.explanation: Diffraction requires wave nature.

questions.question: The principle that explains rectilinear propagation of light is valid when:
options: Wavelength is very small compared to aperture
questions.explanation: Rectilinear propagation holds when wavelength is much smaller than aperture.

questions.question: In Young‚Äôs double slit experiment, the intensity at a point where phase difference is œÄ/3 is proportional to:
questions.explanation: Resultant intensity in interference is proportional to (1+cosœÜ), where œÜ is phase difference.

questions.question: In YDSE, the distance between the third bright fringe on one side and third bright fringe on the other side of the central maximum is:
questions.explanation: Positions are at ¬±3Œ≤, so separation is 6Œ≤.

questions.question: In single slit diffraction, the ratio of angular width of central maximum to that of first secondary maximum is approximately:
questions.explanation: Central maximum is about three times wider than secondary maxima as stated in NCERT.

questions.question: The intensity of first secondary maximum in single slit diffraction is approximately:
questions.explanation: NCERT states first secondary maximum has intensity about 1/9 of central maximum.

questions.question: In diffraction grating, the maximum possible order of diffraction depends on:
questions.explanation: Maximum order is given by n_max = d/Œª.

questions.question: If the grating element is halved, the maximum order of spectrum will:
questions.explanation: Maximum order n_max is proportional to grating element d.

questions.question: In diffraction grating, the angular dispersion increases when:
questions.explanation: Angular dispersion is directly proportional to order of spectrum.

questions.question: The resolving power of a grating depends on:
questions.explanation: Resolving power of grating is proportional to total number of slits.

questions.question: According to Rayleigh criterion, two spectral lines are just resolved when:
options: Principal maximum of one coincides with first minimum of the other
questions.explanation: This is the Rayleigh criterion as per NCERT.

questions.explanation: Finite coherence length limits number of observable fringes.

questions.question: In diffraction grating, the angular width of principal maxima decreases when:
questions.explanation: More slits make principal maxima sharper.

questions.question: In thin film interference, if the film thickness becomes zero, the reflected intensity is:
questions.explanation: Zero thickness leads to destructive interference due to phase reversal.

questions.question: In polarisation, the device used to analyse plane polarised light is called:
questions.explanation: Analyser is used to detect or analyse polarisation.

questions.question: In YDSE, if the slit width is increased significantly, the visibility of fringes will:
questions.explanation: Larger slit width reduces coherence and visibility.

questions.question: In diffraction, the central maximum contains most of the energy because:
questions.explanation: Central maximum is widest and most intense.

questions.question: In polarisation, the phenomenon that proves light is transverse is:
questions.explanation: Only transverse waves can be polarised.

questions.question: In YDSE, if both slits are illuminated by incoherent sources, the observed intensity pattern is:
questions.explanation: Incoherent sources do not produce sustained interference.

questions.question: In diffraction, the phenomenon that limits the resolving power of optical instruments is:
questions.explanation: Diffraction sets the fundamental resolution limit.

questions.explanation: Unpolarised light vibrates in all possible planes perpendicular to propagation.

questions.explanation: Interference and diffraction directly demonstrate wave nature.
